module.p: caidil fall asleep, go to sleep is an intransitive (non-durative) telic verb, with verbal noun cadal
caidil is derived from the Old Gaelic verb con·tuili fall asleep, sleep.
cf. dùisg wake up

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Caidil gu math!
Sleep well! td. 72
Na caidil an sin!
Don’t sleep [lit. fall asleep] there! td. 107
Caidlidh mise an seo.
I’ll sleep [lit. fall asleep] here. td. 107
Cò a chaidleas anns an leabaidh seo?
Who shall sleep [lit. fall asleep] in this bed? td. 107
Thuirt e gun caidleadh e anns a’ chùil.
He said that he would sleep [lit. fall asleep] in the corner. td. 107

Examples from Gairm –
[...] ’S bha iad ’nan suidhe an sin ag òl uisge-beatha fad na h-oidhch’, na ceathrar aca. An dràsda ’s a rithist shealladh Iain a-mach air an uinneig ris a’ mhuir ’s na h-eileanan. [...] Chaidil e airson greiseag ’s nuair a dhùisg e anns a’ mhadainn bha a bheul salach le blas an uisge-bheatha. Choisich e mach ás a’ bhàta a-measg nam faoileagan, ga[n] sguabadh air falbh le a làmhan, agus lean e air suas an aon rathad a bh’ ann gus an ruigeadh e an tigh. [...]
[...] And they were sat there drinking whisky all night, the four of them. Now and again John would look out the window at the sea and the islands. [...] He fell asleep for a while and when he woke up in the morning his mouth was dirty with the taste of the whisky. He walked out of the boat among the gulls, brushing them away with his hands, and he continued up the only road that there was until he reached the house. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
cadal falling asleep, sleeping, sleep is a masculine noun derived from the verb caidil, with genitive form cadail.

bi ’na chadal be asleep is a stative, retrospective verb compound, denoting the state resulting from someone (or something) having falling asleep –
chaidil Iain John fell asleep → tha Iain ’na chadal John is asleep / John has fallen asleep

The possessive determiner fused with the preposition an agrees with the subject of bi in person, number and gender (though note that the disambiguating initial apostrophes are usually dropped in contemporary, post-1970s spelling) –
tha mi ’nam chadal I am asleep / have fallen asleep
tha thu ’nad chadal you are asleep / have fallen asleep
tha i ’na cadal she is asleep / has fallen asleep
tha e ’na chadal he is asleep / has fallen asleep
tha sinn ’nar cadal we are asleep / have fallen asleep
tha sibh ’nur cadal you are asleep / have fallen asleep
tha iad ’nan cadal they are asleep / have fallen asleep

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Bha mi nam chadal anns a’ chathair.
I was sleeping in the chair. td. 107
Bha e na chadal air an langasaid.
He was sleeping on the sofa. td. 107
A bheil thu nad chadal fhathast? Chan eil. ’S ann a tha mi nam dhùisg.
Are you still asleep? No, I am awake. td. 276

Corpus examples –
[...] Bha Ailig na chadal air an t-sòfa, a bhroinn làn uisge-beatha, agus am botal ’s a’ ghlainne air bòrd beag ri thaobh. [...]
[...] Alec was asleep [had fallen asleep] on the sofa, his belly full of whisky, and the bottle and the glass on a little table beside him. [...] td. 110

Older examples –
[...] Ach ged a bha mo shuilean duinte, cha robh mi ’nam chadal idir [...]
[...] But though my eyes were closed, I was not asleep [had not fallen asleep] at all [...] td. 67

tuit ’na chadal fall asleep is a (non-durative) telic verb compound, with the same basic meaning as the verb caidil itself –
thuit mi ’nam chadal ≡ chaidil mi I fell sleep cf. tuit fall

Older examples –
[...] Ghrad thuit thu nad chadal [...]
[...] Suddenly you fell asleep [...] td. 182

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Bhitheadh e a’ coiseachd na chadal.
He used to walk in his sleep. td. 106
An neach nach cinn na chadal, cha chinn e na dhùisg.
He who will not prosper in his sleep, will not prosper when awake. td. 106

Corpus examples –
[...] Dh’fhàg e ’na chadal e trì mìle bho’n uaimh. [...]
[...] He left him asleep three miles from the cave. [...] td. 71

bi a’ cadal be falling asleep is a imperfective verb compound, with two distinct senses –
chaidil Iain John fell asleep →
[progressive] tha Iain a’ cadal (aig an àm seo) John is falling asleep (at this moment)
[habitual] tha Iain a’ cadal anns an sgoil uaireannan John falls asleep at school sometimes
Note that the habitual usage is an informal alternative to the traditional future-tense-as-present-habitual – caidlidh Iain anns an sgoil uaireannan.

Corpus examples –
[...] Aon oidhche chuir e dà dhuine gu taigh an Deucoin airson Rob a phronnadh, ach nuair a bhris iad a-steach bha leabaidh Roib falamh. Bha e air a bhith a’ cadal ann an taigh nàbaidh bho dh’innis Mab dha an cunnart san robh e. [...]
[...] One night he sent two men to the Deacon’s house to rough up Rob, but when they broke in Rob’s bed was empty. He had been sleeping [lit. falling asleep] at a neighbour’s house since Mab told him the danger he was in. [...] td. 115
dèan cadal sleep, go to sleep [Angus Watson]
rach a [do?] chadal go to bed/sleep [Angus Watson]

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
[...] nuair a bha e ga chur a chadal an oidhche sin [...]
[...] when he was putting her to sleep that night [...] td. 107

li.gd: Chan fhaigh i cadal gus an tèid mi dhachaigh.
li.tr: she won’t get any sleep until I get home.

ul.li:
tuit an cadal air fall asleep [cf. caidil, tuit ’na chadal]
Thuit an cadal orm.
Sleep fell upon me. td. 72

li.gd: Bha e eadar a chadal ’s a dhùisg.
li.tr: He was between sleeping and waking.

li.gd: Cha d’fhuair mi norrag chadail a-raoir.
li.tr: I didn't get a wink of sleep last night.

module.p: cadalach sleepy, drowsy, dozy, soporific is an adjective derived from the noun cadal. In certain dialects, the form is cadaltach.

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Dh’èist sinn gu torman cadalach nan calman.
We listened to the drowsy/soporific murmur of the doves. td. 106
’S ann cadalach a bha a’ chlann.
The children were sleepy. td. 106
Bha an cat na shìneadh gu cadalach anns a’ bhlàths.
The cat was stretched out sleepily in the warmth. td. 106
